author: By Eliza Shapiro and Dana Rubinstein
title: Did It Hit 3%? Why Parents and Teachers Are Fixated on One Number
description: Weeks after he managed to reopen the New York City school system, Mayor Bill de Blasio is facing fresh questions about if and when to close it.
content: The news that hundreds of thousands of parents and educators had been awaiting arrived at 9:45 on Sunday morning, in a tweet from Mayor Bill de Blasio: New York City’s test positivity rate remained below 3 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: The four astronauts are minutes from launching to orbit.
description: Four astronauts — three from NASA, one from JAXA, the Japanese space agency — will be sitting inside a SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule, boosted to orbit on top of a Falcon 9 rocket. The mission is known as Crew-1, and the astronauts named their capsule Resilience. They are headed to the International Space Station for a six-month stay.
content: Four astronauts — three from NASA, one from JAXA, the Japanese space agency — will be sitting inside a SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule, boosted to orbit on top of a Falcon 9 rocket. The mission is known as Crew-1, and the astronauts named their capsule Resilience. They are headed to the International Space Station for a six-month stay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Chagall Curtain Needs a New Home With a Tall Ceiling
description: A 65-foot-tall stage curtain that the artist created for the Metropolitan Opera in the 1960s will go up for auction Tuesday at Bonhams.
content: Wanted: art lover with deep pockets and a high ceiling — a very high ceiling. A 65-foot-high ceiling, 20 feet taller than the Hollywood sign, 25 feet taller than a telephone pole and 46 feet taller than a full-grown giraffe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Doctors Are Calling It Quits Under Stress of the Pandemic
description: Thousands of medical practices are closing, as doctors and nurses decide to retire early or shift to less intense jobs.
content: Two years ago, Dr. Kelly McGregory opened her own pediatric practice just outside Minneapolis, where she could spend as much time as she wanted with patients and parents could get all of their questions answered.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 15, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 15, 2020.
content: An article last Sunday about the musical “Lone Star Love,” relying on information from one of the show’s producers, described incorrectly the timing and purpose of an $81,000 payment. The producers Ed and Eleanor Burke made the payment as severance to members of the show’s company before it closed, not to pay a fine by Actors’ Equity against Randy Quaid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: In ‘A Promised Land,’ Barack Obama Thinks — and Thinks Some More — Over His First Term
description: The former president recounts his political ascent and offers close-up views of the major issues he faced during his first years in the White House.
content: The most audacious thing about Barack Obama’s new memoir, “A Promised Land,” is the beaming portrait on its cover: There he is, the 44th president, looking so serenely confident that it’s as if the book weren’t arriving on the heels of a bitter election, amid a cratering economy and a raging pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: It’s time to start planning for Thanksgiving — we can help! — but, in the meantime, keep it simple with a lemon-garlic-kale salad and huli huli chicken.
content: Good morning. Thanksgiving planning begins in earnest today, even if you’ll be serving only yourself on the day. It’s self-care of a sort to clean out the refrigerator and freezer to make room for your disks of pie crust; your unbaked biscuits; your make-ahead stock. It’s self-care to shop for the dry goods you’ll need, the wines you want to drink. The work is soothing and intentional. It has a little hope to it, too: that together, apart, despite the pandemic, we’ll somehow make something special of the holiday this year, sacrificing our usual excess in the name of Thanksgivings to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Mitra Taj
title: Peru’s President Steps Down After Just 6 Days, Leaving Country Adrift
description: Manuel Merino took power after Congress pushed out Peru’s popular president. In office less than a week, he faced mounting opposition from protesters.
content: Facing widespread opposition, Peru’s interim president stepped down on Sunday, his sixth day on the job, plunging a country already facing an economic tailspin and a devastating pandemic into a constitutional crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: After War Between Armenia and Azerbaijan, Peace Sees Winners and Losers Swap Places
description: A deal brokered by Russia ended the fighting for now over Nagorno-Karabakh, leaving Armenians to pack up and burn their houses as they retreat, while Azerbaijanis plan a return to long-lost lands.
content: KELBAJAR, Azerbaijan — The cars, trucks and vans jamming the mountain roads deep into the night on Saturday brimmed with all the possessions that the fleeing Armenians could rescue: upholstered furniture, livestock, glass doors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: The Hot New Covid Tech Is Wearable and Constantly Tracks You
description: Sports leagues, large employers and colleges are turning to devices that could usher in more invasive forms of surveillance.
content: In Rochester, Mich., Oakland University is preparing to hand out wearable devices to students that log skin temperature once a minute — or more than 1,400 times per day — in the hopes of pinpointing early signs of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Ana Swanson
title: China-Led Trade Pact Is Signed, in Challenge to U.S.
description: The deal sealed on Sunday stands as a potent symbol of Beijing’s growing economic sway in Southeast Asia at a time of uncertainty over Washington’s economic ties with the region.
content: BEIJING — After eight years of talks, China and 14 other nations from Japan to New Zealand to Myanmar on Sunday formally signed one of the world’s largest regional free trade agreements, a pact shaped by Beijing partly as a counterweight to American influence in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall, Ali Watkins and Blacki Migliozzi
title: A Watchdog Accused Officers of Serious Misconduct. Few Were Punished.
description: An analysis by The New York Times found that the N.Y.P.D. has reduced or rejected recommendations for stiff discipline of officers in about 71 percent of 6,900 serious misconduct charges.
content: One New York City police officer was accused of pepper-spraying a woman, then denying her medical treatment while she was handcuffed in a Bronx holding cell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Erdogan’s Visit to Northern Cyprus Stokes Decades-Long Dispute
description: The Turkish president visited the island’s Turkish-occupied north, angering Cypriot and Greek officials and inflaming tensions.
content: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey on Sunday visited disputed territory in northern Cyprus that is occupied by Turkish forces, angering Cypriot and Greek leaders and stoking a decades-long conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Dustin Johnson Wins 2020 Masters in Record Fashion
description: Johnson, the No. 1-ranked golfer in the world, won with a score of 20 under par, the first player to reach that total at Augusta National.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — For 10 years, Dustin Johnson’s chase for career-defining, major championship titles was tinged with ruthless angst, misfortune and calamitous setbacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: To Survive the Pandemic, Savile Row Cuts a Bespoke Strategy
description: With formal events and travel canceled, the tradition-bound tailors are gently embracing technology — and finding leverage on their landlords.
content: LONDON — One morning in early November, a tailor on Savile Row took the measurements of a client 5,500 miles away with the help of a robot. The tailor, Dario Carnera, sat on the second floor of Huntsman, one of the street’s most venerable houses, and used the trackpad on his laptop to guide the robot around a client who stood before mirrors in a clothing store in Seoul. Mr. Carnera was visible and audible to the client through an iPad-like panel that doubled as the robot’s face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
title: With Trench Warfare Deepening, Parties Face Unsettled Electoral Map
description: Voters delivered a convincing victory for Joe Biden, but a split decision for the two parties. Now Democrats and Republicans face perhaps the most up-for-grabs electoral landscape in a generation.
content: WASHINGTON — America’s two major parties had hoped the 2020 presidential election would render a decisive judgment on the country’s political trajectory. But after a race that broke records for voter turnout and campaign spending, neither Democrats nor Republicans have achieved a dominant upper hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: When is the launch and how can I watch it?
description: The Crew-1 mission is scheduled to launch on Sunday at 7:27 p.m. Eastern time from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. NASA Television will broadcast coverage beginning at 3:15 p.m. Or you can watch it in the video player at the top of this page.
content: The Crew-1 mission is scheduled to launch on Sunday at 7:27 p.m. Eastern time from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. NASA Television will broadcast coverage beginning at 3:15 p.m. Or you can watch it in the video player at the top of this page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: A Pianist Loses Himself in a Musical ‘Labyrinth’
description: David Greilsammer’s new recording charts a fantastical and disorienting adventure through works spanning centuries.
content: Three years ago, in the underground crypt of a church in Harlem, I watched the pianist David Greilsammer perform “Labyrinth,” a program that daringly juxtaposed pieces from across centuries. As a young man, Mr. Greilsammer had a dream that strange, alluring sounds were guiding him through a labyrinth. This recital was his attempt to share that sensation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Marsh
title: Reinventing the Newspaper, Week After Week
description: What can you make out of The Times? Catapults, roller coasters and piñatas for starters, thanks to the At Home team.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 16, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes and Alexis Soloski
title: When the Critic Is Also the Star. And the Audience.
description: Connection or isolation? Intensity or escape? This spate of shows that put the watcher to work are rewarding, but often in contrasting ways.
content: Could we get a volunteer up here?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Disappearance and Death of Louisiana Teen Raises Questions About Police Response
description: Quawan Charles was found dead in a field in rural Louisiana days after he had vanished. Now his family is asking whether his death could have been prevented with a faster response.
content: Days after his family had reported him missing, Quawan Charles, 15, was found dead in a sugar cane field, more than 20 miles from his home in Baldwin, La., his face badly disfigured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: When a Leader Just Won’t Go
description: Wisdom from Shakespeare to Dickens to ‘Seinfeld’ on President Trump’s long non-goodbye.
content: In Nancy Mitford’s comic 1960 novel “Don’t Tell Alfred,” the wife of the new British ambassador to Paris arrives at the embassy to find that she has a vexing problem: Her predecessor has refused to move out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Hiker Rescued From Mount Rainier Makes ‘Miraculous’ Recovery
description: When Michael Knapinski arrived at a Seattle hospital, his heart stopped for 45 minutes and he was put on life support. Two days later, he was walking.
content: Michael Knapinski was hiking in Mount Rainier National Park last Saturday when he got lost in blinding snow and freezing conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Giants Make a Case to Win the Grim N.F.C. East
description: Daniel Jones threw accurate passes and had a 34-yard touchdown run as the Giants (3-7) moved a half-game back of Philadelphia in the once-grand division.
content: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The N.F.L. isn’t going to disband the N.F.C. East, that wretched assemblage of teams galloping toward collective infamy. Nor, at last check, does it plan to rescind the division’s automatic postseason berth as punishment for producing such unsightly football week after week after week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: With Progressive Politics on March in New Zealand, Maori Minister Blazes New Trails
description: Nanaia Mahuta, the new foreign minister, brings a reputation as an honest broker to Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern’s cabinet, the most diverse in the country’s history.
content: Nanaia Mahuta entered New Zealand’s Parliament as the youngest Maori woman to ever gain a seat. More than two decades later, she has become the country’s minister of foreign affairs, another trailblazing first. So when she was asked at a recent news conference about another woman of color breaking barriers halfway around the world, she broke into a wide smile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wadzanai Mhute
title: After a Writing Break, She Returned as a Booker Finalist
description: Tsitsi Dangarembga’s debut novel, “Nervous Conditions,” made her part of the African literary canon. Decades later, “This Mournable Body” has made her a contender for one of the world’s top book prizes.
content: When Tsitsi Dangarembga’s debut novel “Nervous Conditions” was published in 1988, it was hailed as one of the 20th century’s most significant works of African literature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elsie Chen
title: Her Abuse Was a ‘Family Matter,’ Until It Went Live
description: The grisly death of a farmer, whose attack was streamed online, has shocked China, with many asking why the legal system failed to protect her.
content: Lhamo, a Tibetan farmer in southwestern China, lived her life mostly outdoors and shared it online, posting videos of herself cooking, singing and picking herbs in the mountains around her village. By this fall, she had about 200,000 followers, many of whom praised her as cheerful and hardworking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Masters Mentorship Puts Tournament Rookies on Top
description: On Saturday, 14 first-timers made the rain-delayed cut, a Masters record. Many of them benefited from pretournament sessions with seasoned Masters veterans.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — By the time he reached Augusta National Golf Club’s 17th tee during Monday’s practice round, Cameron Champ had talked with his stand-in coach and tour guide about his upcoming wedding and how to navigate the course’s greens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Judith Levitt
title: Coronavirus Surge, 2020 Election, the Masters: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: ‘Rumble in the Bronx’ Fight Club Drew 200. The Sheriff Shut It Down.
description: The fight club would have been illegal even before the pandemic. Parties in Manhattan and Brooklyn this weekend were also closed down for violating pandemic rules.
content: More than 200 people stood shoulder to shoulder shouting as two men sparred at the center of a Bronx warehouse. Some people hung over the barricades, social media showed, craning their necks for a better view. When one man knocked out the other, the crowd erupted in a thunderous roar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Von Ehren, Andrew Dore and Veronica Yurovsky
title: Not Traveling for the Holidays? ReLAX With an Airport-Related Game
description: Airport codes will finish the Thanksgiving-themed phrases, and the boarding passes reveal a secret image and holiday message.
content: Many Americans won’t be visiting relatives for Thanksgiving this year in light of the pandemic. With this puzzle you can still experience the thrill of travel, minus the crowds. Fill in each Thanksgiving-related phrase on the departure board using airport codes from the boarding passes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Hard Times’
description: How the folk duo Gillian Welch and David Rawlings held onto optimism.
content: In the fall of 2018, Hanif Abdurraqib, the author of today’s narrated story, saw the folk duo Gillian Welch and David Rawlings perform live at an outdoor show in Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Muncy
title: Take the Edge Off With Video Games
description: Unlike loud, stress-inducing shoot-’em-ups, these ones are meant to calm the mind and offer moments of quiet and clarity.
content: Take a deep breath. Hold it for five seconds. Exhale. Breathe in for three seconds. Repeat. How does that feel? A little better? Good. We’re living in stressful times, and any moment of calm is welcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Zuckerman
title: Break the Cycle of Insomnia
description: If you are not sleeping well these days, you’re not alone.
content: It’s 3 a.m. and you’ve been struggling for hours to fall asleep. Morning draws nearer and your anxiety about being exhausted the next day intensifies — yet again. If this sounds familiar, you’re not alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Katherine Cusumano
title: Cook Up Some Scallion Pancakes or Horror Stories
description: Spend the week getting swept up in classic dance, admiring a sloth or listening to Soccer Mommy.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder, Karen Crouse and Bill Pennington
title: The 2020 Masters: Dustin Johnson Sets Scoring Record
description: Dustin Johnson won the Masters at 20 under, five strokes ahead of Australia’s Cameron Smith and Sungjae Im of South Korea.
content: Dustin Johnson won the 2020 Masters and set a scoring record at 20 under par, two strokes better than the former record, held jointly by Tiger Woods and Jordan Spieth. Johnson, who grew up an hour away, in South Carolina, became the first world No. 1 to win the event since Woods in 2001.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: Want a Preview of President Biden? Look to the Campaign Trail
description: He is returning to a Washington he knows well. And the path he took to get back offers a road map for how he’ll govern.
content: Like President Bill Clinton, Joseph R. Biden Jr. is an empathetic extrovert with a sprawling network of friends. Like President George W. Bush, he maintains strict personal discipline (for Mr. Biden, that meant Peloton rides and protein shakes this year, to offset an ice cream habit).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: The Vaccine Boost
description: Markets rallied around promising vaccine trials, but soaring infection rates show that the worst may be yet to come.
content: Greetings from the four walls of my apartment, which I don’t plan to leave until I drive to my parents’ house for Thanksgiving. Forecasters are predicting a drop in travel by at least 10 percent for the holiday, but health officials hope even more people stay put. Be safe and enjoy those early Black Friday sales from your couch. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Stenquist
title: It’s Time to Tackle the Garage
description: There is supposed to be room for cars and you’re probably never going to use that old paint. Here’s how to bring order to your home’s last messy place.
content: Days spent at home have moved even the most muddled people to organize. The spice rack now displays alphabetically ordered bottles in neat rows. The closet has sections for formal and informal wear, subdivided by season. Pots and pans are arranged by type, the silverware drawer is a model of organizational excellence. But the garage is still overflowing with who-knows-what, piled here, there and everywhere. Time to organize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Simon Marks
title: They Once Ruled Ethiopia. Now They Are Fighting Its Government.
description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed’s two-year feud with the rebellious ruling party of the Tigray region has exploded into a war, with bombings, massacres and ethnic divisions, that threatens to upend the entire Horn of Africa.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — When it comes to mountain warfare, the people of Tigray — an ancient kingdom in the far north of Ethiopia, spread across jagged peaks and lush farmland — have decades of hard-won experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Victor Glover will be the first Black crew member on the space station.
description: NASA, which has worked to spotlight the “hidden figures” in its history, but has so far sent only 14 Black Americans to space.
content: In the 20-some years that people have been living aboard the International Space Station, its extended crew has never included a Black astronaut. Victor J. Glover, a Navy commander and test pilot who joined the astronaut corps in 2013, will be the first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alfonso Flores Bermúdez, Allyson Waller and Neil Vigdor
title: Iota, Barreling Toward Central America, Becomes a Category 4 Hurricane
description: The storm, the second hurricane to strike Central America in less than two weeks, was expected to produce catastrophic winds and up to 30 inches of rain all week.
content: PUERTO CABEZAS, Nicaragua — Iota was upgraded to a Category 4 hurricane early Monday morning, the National Hurricane Center said, warning that the storm was likely to bring catastrophic winds, life-threatening storm surge and extreme rainfall to Central America, an area still recovering from Hurricane Eta less than two weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Catch the Vibe: Club Culture Comes to Life at Lincoln Center
description: The choreographer Ephrat Asherie unveils her short film “UnderScored,” which pays homage to the history of the underground scene and its veterans.
content: It’s more than just another dance film born during the pandemic, because it is more than a dance. It’s a celebration of a culture: the underground scene of New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg and Nick Corasaniti
title: Behind Trump’s Yearslong Effort to Turn Losing Into Winning
description: Even before he was elected in 2016, Donald J. Trump was building a conspiracy theory about voter fraud that took on new energy this year, as his political fortunes ebbed during the coronavirus pandemic.
content: The trouble broke out inside the main counting room in Detroit late on the morning of Nov. 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ileana Ros-Lehtinen and Ken Salazar
title: Where Is the Smithsonian Museum for American Latinos?
description: Our stories still don’t have a permanent home in our nation’s capital.
content: The National Mall in Washington is where we inaugurate presidents, march for change and learn about America’s history at monuments and the Smithsonian Institution museums. And yet, even as Latinos have helped shape this great nation, our stories don’t have a permanent home in our nation’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Tiger Woods Faced Disaster at the Masters. He Stuck Through It Anyway.
description: After a horrific appearance at No. 12, the five-time Masters winner did not fade — even with no hope of another green jacket and almost no one around to watch.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods had just birdied three holes on Sunday at the Masters when he stood at the tee box at No. 18. A few of the men sitting around the 17th green did not bother to watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Readers Have Been Eagerly Waiting for Barack Obama’s New Memoir. Struggling Booksellers Have, Too.
description: “A Promised Land” is a potential lifeline for booksellers whose sales have plummeted during the pandemic.
content: Shortly after President Barack Obama left office in 2017, in the aftermath of a contentious election that cost his party the presidency, he sat down with a yellow notepad and began writing an account of his time in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: China and 14 other countries sign huge regional trade deal.
content: China and 14 other nations from Japan to New Zealand signed one of the world’s largest regional free trade agreements on Sunday. The pact, which took eight years to negotiate, could help further cement China as the dominant economic power in its neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Lewis Hamilton Ties Schumacher’s Seven Formula One Titles
description: Hamilton equaled Michael Schumacher’s championship record with a win at the Grand Prix of Turkey.
content: ISTANBUL — Lewis Hamilton clinched a record-equaling seventh Formula One title after winning a wet and gloomy Turkish Grand Prix for a record-extending 94th victory on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Estrin
title: Staying Apart, But Praying Together
description: As the coronavirus surges again, houses of worship in New York struggle to serve their communities safely.
content: Emilio Arteaga, the beloved longtime deacon at St. Agatha’s, a Roman Catholic church in Brooklyn, died from Covid-19 on Good Friday this year. It was not until 10 days later that just a handful of priests and nuns were able to mark the occasion by reciting a single prayer over his casket, in the middle of 49th Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Succeed in Life
description: Jennifer Nutt’s Monday puzzle puts us through our paces.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — This is a really fun grid to start the week! I think the theme builds like a midweek construction; its author, Jennifer Nutt, has made puzzles for Mondays through Wednesdays in the past. One thing that makes it a Monday puzzle is the revealer, with a clear explanation of what you’re looking for; I feel that there’s a thematic Easter egg in the downs, though, and I just love that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Largely Out of Sight in Washington, Kamala Harris Preps for White House
description: Ms. Harris has barely appeared on the public radar since her acceptance speech last Saturday in Wilmington, Del., where she declared “a new day for America.”
content: WASHINGTON — At a chic cafe in the West End neighborhood here, a young waiter knew that the incoming vice president lived “upstairs,” as he noted by gesturing to an upscale condominium building overhead, but said he had not actually seen her lately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $675,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Sex-Abuse Claims Against Boy Scouts Now Surpass 82,000
description: The deluge of sex-abuse filings, coming ahead of a bankruptcy deadline, far surpasses the number of claims filed in Catholic Church cases.
content: More than 82,000 people have come forward with sex-abuse claims against the Boy Scouts of America, describing a decades-long accumulation of assaults at the hands of scout leaders across the nation who had been trusted as role models.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elissa Sanci
title: Your Guide to Black Friday Shopping
description: Watch out for “deals” that aren’t really deals.
content: Black Friday, once a one-day blowout sale, has steadily ballooned over the past few years. Black Friday is now, in essence, Cyber Month — it’s not uncommon to see Black Friday sales promoted weeks ahead of the day itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Faces Early Test With Immigration and Homeland Security After Trump
description: The Department of Homeland Security was molded in President Trump’s image, and not just on immigration policy. President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will have work to do to remake it.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has said that one of his first priorities will be rolling back his predecessor’s restrictive immigration policies. To do it, he may have to overhaul the Department of Homeland Security, which has been bent to President Trump’s will over the past four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Dustin Johnson Widens Masters Lead and Eyes Scoring Record
description: The No. 1-ranked golfer played in one lead-up event before the Masters after a positive coronavirus test felled him in October. Despite the rust, he leads the field by four strokes after three rounds.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Perhaps it is fitting that the player leading the biggest golf tournament of 2020 prepared for the event last month by self-isolating in a hotel room for 11 days after a positive coronavirus test result.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Egypt Unearths New Mummies Dating Back 2,500 Years
description: More than 100 painted wooden coffins, many with bodies, were found in the necropolis of Saqqara, officials said. After several recent finds at the site, it’s the largest discovery there this year.
content: Archaeologists in Egypt have unearthed more than 100 delicately painted wooden coffins, some with mummies inside, and 40 funeral statues in the ancient burial ground of Saqqara, the Egyptian antiquities authorities said, calling the discovery the largest find at the site this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Roger Jepsen, Senator From Iowa and Reagan Ally, Dies at 91
description: A voice for farmers, he lost a re-election bid after it was disclosed that he had joined a health spa that was shut down on prostitution charges.
content: Roger W. Jepsen, an Iowa Republican and Reagan administration ally who served one term in the Senate before losing a 1984 re-election bid after it was revealed that he had joined a private health spa that was later shut down on prostitution charges, died on Friday in Bettendorf, Iowa. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: States Aren’t Ready to Distribute Shots
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 15, 2020.
content: “This is going to be a phenomenal logistical feat, to vaccinate everybody in the country. We absolutely have zero margin for failure. We really have to get this right.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘It Was Hard Not to Eavesdrop on the Two Men at the Next Table’
description: At lunch in a busy restaurant, a homework assignment on the roof and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kerr and Natalie Reneau
title: Swing State Voters Look to the Future
description: In the days after the election, Times reporters went to four swing state counties with some of the tightest vote margins to see how people were feeling. The answer? Still pretty divided.
content: In the days after the election, Times reporters went to four swing state counties with some of the tightest vote margins to see how people were feeling. The answer? Still pretty divided.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: Take a Break From Political Comedy With These Podcasts
description: Now that the election is in the rearview mirror, release the last of the tension with funny audio shows on the lighter side of things.
content: Having trouble sleeping lately? Racing thoughts? Agita? Perhaps you are looking to ease the emotional hangover from that nail-biter of a presidential election. Utterly apolitical podcasts are just the ticket. These shows are not current events- or pop culture-based. They are not trying to teach you anything. They do not seek to challenge you, or stretch your brain in any way. Instead, the hosts of these shows have one goal: to make you laugh. Tuning in to any of these goofy podcasts to relax, unwind and giggle.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When Politics Drives a Wedge Within Families
